Incorporating strength training into your routine can definitely help improve your overall performance in the triathlon. Here are some exercises and routines that can benefit a triathlete like you:

**Core Exercises:**

1. Plank: Hold a plank position for 30-60 seconds, rest for 30 seconds, and repeat for 3-4 sets.
2. Russian twists: Use a medicine ball or weight plate and twist your torso from side to side, targeting your obliques. Do 3 sets of 12-15 reps.
3. Leg raises: Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and raise your legs straight up towards the ceiling. Lift your shoulders off the ground and hold for 1-2 seconds. Do 3 sets of 12-15 reps.
4. Bicycle crunches: Lie on your back with your hands behind your head and alternate bringing your knees towards your chest, as if pedaling a bicycle. Do 3 sets of 12-15 reps.

**Leg Exercises:**

1. Squats: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and squat down, keeping your back straight and your knees behind your toes. Do 3 sets of 12-15 reps.
2. Lunges: Stand with your feet together and take a large step forward with one foot. Lower your body down into a lunge, keeping your back straight and your front knee behind your toes. Do 3 sets of 12-15 reps per leg.
3. Calf raises: Stand on a step or platform and raise up onto your toes, then lower back down. Do 3 sets of 12-15 reps.
4. Deadlifts: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a weight or barbell with your hands shoulder-width apart. Lift the weight up to hip level, squeezing your glutes and pushing your hips back. Do 3 sets of 8-10 reps.

As for local gyms or fitness studios in the downtown area, I don't have real-time access to specific locations. However, I can suggest a few ways to find a gym or studio that suits your needs:

1. Online search: Use search engines like Google to look for gyms or fitness studios in the downtown area. You can filter your search by location, hours of operation, and services offered.
2. Social media: Check social media platforms like Facebook or Instagram to see if local gyms or fitness studios have pages or accounts. You can read reviews, look at their schedules, and get a sense of their community.
3. Ask around: Ask your friends, colleagues, or fellow triathletes for recommendations. They might have experience with local gyms or studios that offer strength training classes or personal training sessions.
4. Check with your insurance: If you have health insurance, check if they have partnerships with local gyms or fitness studios that offer discounts or promotions.

Remember to always consult with a healthcare professional or certified personal trainer before starting any new exercise routine. They can help you create a personalized plan that suits your fitness level and goals.
